in: ✈ ♻ Free movement: Around 1.3 million Brits 🌴 live abroad in the EU, and having membership makes travel easier
💷 ⬆Prices would rise: Flights, energy and 📱 phone tariffs are all at risk of going up in price if we leave the EU
💪 👥 Deal-making power: The EU negotiates 💡 energy deals as a large, supposedly stronger, bloc
💰 🎁 Buying & Selling: Britain is the EU’s largest trading partner 40+% of GB exports go to the EU & 50+% of GB products  come from the EU
📦 📜 Trading rules: Even after Brexit, Britain may still have to comply with EU rules to trade with EU countries
📉 🚧 Slower growth: If we left the EU an estimated £36bn would be lost per year due to slower growth
💪 👥 Stronger in: In a competitive, 🌍 globalised world  the UK needs to stay in the EU to help shape laws which affect the UK from the inside
✌ 👊 UK government’s 🇬🇧 ability to influence policies occurs both in voting and in negotiations over the text of a draft law
💝 👍 Helpful laws: Many EU laws benefit the UK, for instance the new EU CAP will invest £22 billion over the next 7 years
✈ ✅ Migrants benefit us: EU citizens living in Britain 💸 pay more in taxes than they receive in benefits
🔧 🔩 Tightening rules: Benefits for new EU migrant workers will soon be limited for the first four years
out: 🙊 💬 Limited power: The UK Government can only do so much to 🚷 reduce immigration due to the rules of being in the EU
🐌 🔀 Slow to change: The UK 🆕🚫can’t change certain legislation without it going through the EU, which often ⏳ takes longer like the infamous tampon tax
💡 👌 Energy independent: Most of our 💨 gas imports come from Norway – Britain is not dependent on Russia
💰 🎁 Handing over cash: We have paid around £380 billion to the EU since we joined in the 70s, adjusting for inflation - this money could have been spent directly on British public services
📜 💳 Terms and conditions: Much of the money we get straight back from the EU comes with instructions on how to spend it - a Brexit would mean we can dictate where it goes
🐾 🚸 Trodden path: Britain could emulate countries like Norway or Switzerland, both prosperous and with a high standard-of-living, and re-establish trade links with EU states
💪 💬 Big influence: Between 10% and 55% of UK laws and regulations🌱stem from the EU
🙋 🚶 Voted out: In recent years the UK has been on the losing side of fighting EU laws, and now loses a higher proportion of votes than any other member
⛔ 🚷 Held back: Open Europe estimates that the 100 most expensive EU regulations set back the UK economy by £27.4 billion a year
🔓 ⚠ Lacking control: Immigration can only be controlled so much when you’re an EU member
🚷 🚪 Security risks: The Schengen Area means someone crossing the channel could have entered Europe from almost any bordering country
